definitions: barely sufficient or adequate in amount, quantity, or extent
giving limited or insufficient attention, consideration, or treatment to something
examples: The recipe calls for scant tablespoon of sugar
There was scant evidence to support the claim
The report paid scant attention to environmental concerns
She showed scant regard for safety regulations

definitions: small or insufficient in quantity or amount; barely adequate
describing clothing that reveals much of the body due to minimal fabric
examples: The scanty rainfall left crops withering in fields
Information about the ancient civilization remains scanty
She wore scanty beachwear that barely covered essentials
The dancer's scanty costume sparkled under stage lights

definitions: insufficient for the demand; in short supply relative to need
rarely found or seen; occurring, found, or observed infrequently
examples: Fresh water became scarce during the drought
Jobs were scarce in the economic downturn
Such honest politicians are scarce these days
Original manuscripts from that era are extremely scarce

definitions: of a brilliant red color with a slight orange tinge
associated with sin, shame, or moral wrongdoing in literature
examples: She wore a scarlet dress to the gala
The scarlet maple leaves signaled autumn's arrival
The scarlet letter marked her public shame
His scarlet past haunted his political career

definitions: bearing permanent marks on skin or surface from injury or damage
showing lasting emotional or psychological damage from traumatic experiences
examples: His scarred hands told stories of hard labor
The scarred landscape showed effects of wildfire
She remained scarred by childhood trauma years later
The scarred veteran struggled with civilian life

definitions: witheringly scornful; severely critical in a way that damages or hurts
examples: The critic wrote a scathing review of the performance
She delivered a scathing indictment of government policies
His scathing remarks left the audience stunned
The report contained scathing criticism of management

definitions: distributed or occurring at widely spaced intervals over an area
lacking concentration or focus; mentally disorganized or distracted
examples: Scattered showers are expected throughout the day
The scattered villages dotted the mountainous landscape
She felt scattered after working three different jobs
His scattered thoughts made studying difficult

definitions: providing or relating to views of impressive or beautiful natural scenery
examples: We took the scenic route along the coastline
The scenic overlook offered breathtaking mountain views
This scenic highway attracts thousands of tourists annually
They chose a scenic location for wedding photographs

definitions: having fragrance added artificially through perfume or other means
naturally giving off a pleasant smell or aroma
examples: She lit scented candles to create ambiance
The scented soap left skin smelling like lavender
The scented garden bloomed with roses and jasmine
Scented pine needles carpeted the forest floor

definitions: not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations about something
examples: Scientists remained sceptical about the new findings
She was sceptical of his promises after past disappointments
The sceptical audience questioned every claim made
He adopted a sceptical approach to investment schemes

definitions: arranged or planned to happen at a particular time
included in an official list or timetable of planned events
examples: The scheduled meeting was postponed until next week
Your scheduled appointment is at three o'clock
This is a scheduled flight departing daily
The scheduled maintenance will minimize equipment failures

definitions: represented in simplified form as a diagram showing essential features
arranged according to a fixed plan or organized pattern
examples: The engineer drew a schematic diagram of circuits
This schematic representation shows system connections clearly
Her schematic approach to problem-solving proved effective
The novel follows a schematic three-act structure

definitions: given to making secret and dishonest plans to achieve goals
examples: The scheming villain plotted against the hero
Her scheming nature made colleagues distrust her
The scheming politicians formed secret alliances
His scheming ambition knew no ethical bounds

definitions: relating to or causing division within a religious organization
characterized by or promoting division or discord within any group
examples: The schismatic movement split the church in two
His schismatic teachings were condemned by church leaders
The schismatic debate divided party members irreconcilably
Their schismatic approach fractured the organization

definitions: characterized by emotional aloofness and solitary habits typical of schizoid personality
containing contradictory or antagonistic qualities or attitudes
examples: His schizoid personality made forming relationships difficult
The schizoid patient preferred complete isolation
The company's schizoid policies confused both employees and customers
Her schizoid artistic style combined opposing elements

definitions: relating to or suffering from schizophrenia mental disorder
characterized by wildly contradictory or inconsistent elements
examples: The schizophrenic patient required specialized medical care
Schizophrenic symptoms include hallucinations and delusions
The market showed schizophrenic behavior all week
His schizophrenic policy positions confused voters

definitions: involving or relating to serious academic study and research standards
examples: Her scholarly article was published in peer-reviewed journal
The professor maintained scholarly demeanor during debates
This scholarly edition includes extensive footnotes and commentary
His scholarly approach impressed the academic committee

definitions: of or concerning schools, education, and academic achievement
relating to medieval philosophy taught in universities
examples: Her scholastic achievements earned multiple scholarship offers
The scholastic year begins in early September
Medieval scholastic philosophers debated theological questions
His scholastic method emphasized logical argumentation

definitions: brilliantly and excitingly clever or skillful in performance
sparkling or shining brightly with flashes of light
examples: Her scintillating wit entertained dinner guests all evening
The debate featured scintillating exchanges between candidates
The scintillating diamonds caught every ray of light
Stars appeared as scintillating points against darkness

definitions: burned or discolored by exposure to flames or heat
made extremely dry by prolonged heat or drought conditions
examples: The scorched pan required extensive scrubbing to clean
Fire left scorched marks across the hillside
The scorched earth cracked under relentless summer sun
Scorched lawns showed effects of water restrictions

definitions: very hot; burning or parching with intense heat
severely critical or scathing in tone or manner
examples: The scorching desert sun made travel dangerous
Scorching temperatures broke records across the region
She delivered a scorching critique of the proposal
His scorching sarcasm silenced the hecklers

definitions: having no points scored by either side in a game
examples: The match remained scoreless through overtime period
Both teams played excellent defense in scoreless game
The scoreless tie frustrated fans expecting offensive fireworks
After three scoreless innings, tension filled the stadium

definitions: rejected or dismissed with contempt or derision by others
examples: The scorned lover plotted elaborate revenge schemes
His scorned proposal became motivation for success
She felt scorned by former friends after scandal
The scorned artist later achieved international recognition

definitions: of or relating to Scotland, its people, or culture
examples: He ordered scotch whisky neat at the bar
The scotch plaid pattern adorned her winter scarf
Traditional scotch music filled the highland festival
The scotch terrier won best in show

definitions: cleaned or polished by hard rubbing with abrasive material
searched thoroughly and systematically through an area or resource
examples: The scoured pot gleamed like new after cleaning
Wind and sand scoured the ancient stone smooth
Police scoured the neighborhood for missing child
Researchers scoured archives for historical documents

definitions: mixed together in a confused or disordered way
describing eggs beaten and cooked while stirring
examples: The scrambled signals made communication impossible
His scrambled thoughts reflected extreme exhaustion
She prepared scrambled eggs with cheese for breakfast
The diner serves perfectly scrambled eggs

definitions: having a determined, argumentative, or aggressive spirit
consisting of disorganized fragments or scraps pieced together
examples: The scrappy underdog team surprised everyone by winning
Her scrappy attitude helped overcome numerous obstacles
His scrappy collage used various recycled materials
The scrappy quilt combined leftover fabric pieces

definitions: having a rough texture that causes itching or irritation
producing a rough, harsh, or grating sound quality
examples: The scratchy wool sweater irritated sensitive skin
His throat felt scratchy from seasonal allergies
The old record player produced scratchy music
Her scratchy voice suggested she had been crying

definitions: producing loud, high-pitched cries or sounds
extremely obvious, conspicuous, or attention-grabbing
examples: The screaming child disrupted the entire restaurant
Screaming fans greeted the celebrity at airport
The screaming headlines announced the scandal
Her screaming pink dress stood out dramatically

definitions: crazy or eccentric in an amusing, harmless way
examples: His screwball comedy routines delighted audiences
The screwball professor wore mismatched shoes daily
This screwball idea might actually work brilliantly
Her screwball sense of humor lightened tense meetings

definitions: written out in advance as a script to be followed
appearing rehearsed or artificial rather than natural or spontaneous
examples: The actor delivered scripted lines with perfect timing
Politicians often give scripted responses to media
Their scripted conversation felt awkward and forced
The supposedly spontaneous moment seemed completely scripted

definitions: relating to or contained in sacred religious writings or scriptures
examples: The minister based his sermon on scriptural passages
Her scriptural knowledge impressed theology professors
They sought scriptural guidance for moral decisions
The scriptural interpretation sparked theological debate

definitions: describing vegetation that is stunted or inferior in growth
of inferior quality, size, or social standing
examples: Scrub oak covered the dry hillsides
The scrub pine thrived in poor soil
The scrub team practiced against varsity players
He dismissed it as scrub work beneath him

definitions: cleaned thoroughly by rubbing hard with brush or cloth
cancelled, abandoned, or called off, especially at last minute
examples: Her scrubbed face glowed with healthy cleanliness
The scrubbed floor sparkled under bright lights
The mission was scrubbed due to weather
They scrubbed their vacation plans after emergency

definitions: covered with stunted trees or inferior vegetation growth
shabby, unkempt, or inferior in appearance or quality
examples: The scrubby wasteland stretched for miles
Goats grazed on scrubby Mediterranean hillsides
His scrubby beard needed professional grooming
The scrubby motel barely met basic standards

definitions: shabby and untidy or unkempt in appearance or condition
examples: The scruffy dog needed grooming and bath
His scruffy appearance concerned job interviewers
The scruffy apartment hadn't been cleaned in months
She preferred his scruffy charm to polished looks

definitions: diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details
having moral integrity; guided by conscience in all actions
examples: The accountant kept scrupulous records of expenses
She paid scrupulous attention to research methodology
His scrupulous honesty earned everyone's trust
The judge maintained scrupulous fairness throughout trial

definitions: shaped or carved from material as a work of art
having well-defined muscles or contours as if artistically shaped
examples: The sculpted marble statue adorned the museum
Artists sculpted intricate details into soft clay
His sculpted abs showed years of training
Her sculpted features resembled classical beauty

definitions: having qualities of or resembling sculpture in form or artistic effect
examples: The building's sculptural design won architectural awards
Her sculptural hairstyle defied gravity impressively
The sculptural quality of shadows created dramatic effects
Desert rocks showed sculptural forms carved by wind

definitions: shaped or molded with the artistic qualities of sculpture
examples: The sculptured fountain became a tourist attraction
Her sculptured nails featured intricate artistic designs
Wind created sculptured sand dunes in desert
The sculptured hedge maze delighted garden visitors

definitions: contemptibly mean, worthless, or showing a malicious nature
examples: That was a scurvy trick to play on friends
The scurvy knave betrayed his master's trust
His scurvy behavior at dinner shocked everyone
She condemned his scurvy treatment of employees

definitions: transported by or taking place on the sea
examples: Seaborne trade dominated the ancient economy
The seaborne invasion required massive naval support
Most seaborne cargo travels in container ships
Seaborne commerce faces increasing piracy threats

definitions: engaged in or connected with traveling or working at sea
examples: The seafaring nation built a powerful navy
His seafaring ancestors were merchant sailors
Seafaring life demands physical and mental toughness
The museum displays seafaring artifacts and tools

definitions: designed or suitable for traveling on the open sea
examples: The seagoing vessel weathered storms successfully
Only seagoing ships can handle ocean crossings
He earned his seagoing certification after training
The seagoing yacht featured advanced navigation equipment

definitions: fastened or closed securely to prevent access or leakage
officially confirmed or made definite and unchangeable
examples: The sealed envelope contained confidential documents
Keep medicine in sealed containers for freshness
The sealed agreement ended months of negotiations
Their sealed fate became clear after verdict

definitions: having no visible seams, joints, or interruptions in material
smooth and continuous, with no apparent gaps or spaces
examples: The seamless garment showed masterful construction
Modern technology enables seamless steel tubes
The seamless transition between scenes impressed viewers
Their seamless cooperation produced excellent results

definitions: dried up, withered, or no longer green and fresh
examples: The sear leaves crunched underfoot in autumn
Drought left sear grass throughout the prairie
His sear hopes for reconciliation finally died
The sear landscape looked desolate and barren

definitions: thoroughly investigating or exploring to find something
keenly observant and penetrating in examination or inquiry
examples: Her searching questions revealed hidden truths
The detective began searching investigation of crime
His searching gaze made her feel exposed
The searching examination uncovered several discrepancies

definitions: extremely hot or burning with intense heat
severely critical or painfully harsh in effect
examples: The searing heat made outdoor work dangerous
Searing pain shot through his injured shoulder
Her searing indictment of corruption sparked reforms
The movie offered searing commentary on poverty

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a particular season
fluctuating or available according to the season
examples: Seasonal allergies affected her every spring
The store hired seasonal workers for holidays
Seasonal fruits taste best when naturally ripe
Tourism showed typical seasonal patterns of activity
